revision.text:
[[File:Phallic tombstone.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Phallic tombstone]] '''Phallic architecture''' consciously or unconsciously creates a symbolic representation of the [[phallus]].<ref name="AmbroseHarris2008">{{cite book|last1=Ambrose|first1=Gavin|last2=Harris|first2=Paul|last3=Stone|first3=Sally|title=The Visual Dictionary of Architecture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Aml4RjvWaB4C&pg=PA199|accessdate=12 September 2012|date=1 February 2008 |location=Lausanne, Switzerland New York, N.Y |publisher=AVA Publishing SA Distributed in the USA & Canada by Watson-Guptill Publications|isbn=978-2-940373-54-3|page=199}}</ref> Buildings intentionally or unintentionally resembling the human penis are a source of amusement to locals and tourists in various places around the world. Deliberate phallic imagery is found in ancient cultures and in the links to ancient cultures found in traditional artifacts.
The [[Ancient Greece|ancient Greeks]] and [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] celebrated phallic festivals and built a shrine with an erect phallus to honor [[Hermes]], messenger of the gods. Those figures may be related to the [[ancient Egypt]]ian deity [[Min (god)|Min]] who was depicted holding his erect phallus. Figures of women with a phallus for a head have been found across Greece and [[Yugoslavia]]. Phallic symbolism was prevalent in the architectural tradition of ancient [[Babylon]]. The [[Romans]], who were deeply superstitious, also often used phallic imagery in their architecture and domestic items. The ancient cultures of many parts of the [[Far East]], including [[Indonesia]], [[India]], [[Korea]] and [[Japan]], used the phallus as a symbol of fertility in motifs on their temples and in other areas of everyday life.
Scholars of [[anthropology]], [[sociology]], and [[feminism]] have pointed out the symbolic nature of phallic architecture, especially large [[skyscrapers]] which dominate the landscape as symbols of male domination, power and political authority. Towers and other vertical structures may unintentionally or perhaps subconsciously have those connotations. There are many examples of modern architecture that can be interpreted as phallic, but very few for which the architect has specifically cited or admitted that meaning as an intentional aspect of the design.
==History and background==
===Antiquity=== [[File:Phallic Pre-History items at Auberge de Provence 01.jpg|thumb|Phallic [[Pre-History|Temple period]] (4,000 - 25,000 B.C.) items at the [[National Museum of Archaeology, Malta|National Museum of Archaeology]], Malta<ref>Sagina, Claudia (2015), [https://books.google.com.mt/books?id=qR5TCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA104 The Archeology of Malta], Cambridge University Press, {{ISBN|9781107006690}}, p. 104.</ref>]]
The worship of the phallus has existed since the [[Stone Age]], and was particularly prevalent during the [[Neolithic]] period and the [[Bronze Age]].<ref name="Patrick2008">{{cite book|last=Patrick|first=John|title=Huge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pdREL8ufWpgC&pg=PA9|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=30 May 2008|publisher=STARbooks Press|isbn=978-1-934187-29-6|page=9}}</ref>
Phallic architecture became prominent in [[ancient Egypt]] and Greece, where genitalia and human sexuality received a high degree of attention. The ancient Greeks honored the phallus and celebrated phallic festivals.<ref name="GretherKramer2012">{{cite book|last1=Grether|first1=Bruce P.|last2=Kramer|first2=Joseph|last3=Johnson|first3=Toby|title=The Secret of the Golden Phallus: Male Erotic Alchemy for the 21st Century|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KF7zviQJwOAC&pg=PA114|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=30 March 2012|publisher=[[Lethe Press]]|isbn=978-1-59021-118-2|page=114}}</ref> The Greco-Roman deity [[Priapus]] was worshiped as a god of fertility, depicted with a giant phallus in numerous public architectural pieces.<ref name="Patrick2008"/>
The Greeks regularly built a shrine which they called "Herm" at the entrance of major public buildings, homes and along roads to honor [[Hermes]], messenger of the gods.<ref name="Westmoreland2007">{{cite book|last=Westmoreland|first=Perry L.|title=Ancient Greek Beliefs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=v8AvHMepO8wC&pg=PA627|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=30 June 2007|publisher=Lee And Vance Publishing Co|isbn=978-0-9793248-1-9|page=627}}</ref> The shrines typically "took the form of a vertical pillar topped by the bearded head of a man and from the surface of the pillar below the head, an erect phallus protruded".<ref name="GretherKramer2012"/> It is believed that they sought their inspiration from the ancient Egyptians and their phallic image of [[Min (god)|Min]], the valley god, who was similarly "depicted as a standing bearded king with simplified body, one arm raised, the other hand holding his erect phallus."<ref name="GretherKramer2012"/>
[[Herodotus]], the ancient Greek historian, documented women carrying large phallic shaped monuments and ornaments the size of a human body in villages in ancient [[Dionysia]].<ref name="Bloch2003">{{cite book|last=Bloch|first=Iwan|title=Anthropological Studies in the Strange Sexual Practices of All Races in All Ages|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3PEqvj5MJ7AC&pg=PA119|accessdate=12 September 2012|date=1 March 2003|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|isbn=978-0-7661-3382-2|page=119}}</ref> On the island of [[Delos]] a pillar supports a colossal phallus, the symbol of [[Dionysus]]. Phallus reliefs on buildings on such sites are also believed to have been apotropaic devices to ward off evil.<ref name="GlazebrookHenry2011">{{cite book|last1=Glazebrook|first1=Allison|last2=Henry|first2=Madeleine M.|title=Greek Prostitutes in the ancient Mediterranean, 800 BCE–200 CE|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8XXabZhMMhsC&pg=PA160|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=6 January 2011|publisher=Univ of Wisconsin Press|isbn=978-0-299-23564-2|page=160}}</ref> The elaborate use of phallic architecture and sculpture in ancient Greek society can also be seen in sites such as [[Nea Nikomedeia]] in northern Greece. Archaeologists excavating the ancient town discovered clay sculptures of plump women with phallic heads and folded arms.<ref name="Gimbutas1974">{{cite book|last=Gimbutas|first=Marija Alseikaitė|title=The Gods and Goddesses of Old Europe: 7000 to 3500 BC Myths, Legends and Cult Images|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SLACTsmH4aYC&pg=PA153|accessdate=16 September 2012|year=1974|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-01995-9|page=153}}</ref>
Similar figurines of women with phallus heads from the Neolithic period have been found across Greece, Macedonia and parts of old Yugoslavia. The vast majority of the figurines of the [[Hamangia culture]] have cylindrical phallus-shaped heads without facial features, although some, particularly of the [[Aegean culture]], had phallic sculptural pieces with phallic heads with a pinched nose and slitty eyes.<ref name="Gimbutas1974"/> In these parts of the ancient world, [[obelisk]] like structures resembling the [[human penis]] were built, often with phallic symbols, representing human fertility and asserting male sexuality and orgasm.<ref name="AmbroseHarris2008"/> Phallic symbolism was prevalent in the architecture of ancient Babylonia, and in Khametian iconography, the obelisk was considered to be symbolic of the phallus of the masculine earth.<ref name="Hannay1991">{{cite book|last=Hannay|first=James Ballantyne|title=Sex Symbolism in Religion|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=90VzHRzJm7sC&pg=PA522|accessdate=12 September 2012|date=1 August 1991|publisher=Health Research Books|isbn=978-0-7873-0367-9|page=522}}</ref> The obelisks of ancient Egypt themselves had several functions, existing both as a reference to the cultus of the sun and of the phallus, representing fertility and power.<ref name="MacKenzie2002">{{cite book|last=MacKenzie|first=Kenneth R. H.|title=Royal Masonic Cyclopaedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YMT_gQblxB8C&pg=PA521|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=1 July 2002|publisher=Kessinger Publishing|isbn=978-0-7661-2611-4|page=521}}</ref>
{{double image|right|Pompeya erótica6.jpg|195|Delos phallus.jpg|220|Left: The well-endowed [[Priapus]], the Greco-Roman god of fertility. He was the subject of many architectural works in the ancient world. Right: A phallic column in [[Delos]]}} Although phallic architecture as individual pieces was not prevalent in [[ancient Rome]] as it was in ancient Greece or Egypt, the Romans were deeply superstitious and often introduced phallus-related components as architectural pieces and domestic items. Archaeologists unearthing a site in [[Pompei]] discovered many vases, ornaments and sculptures unearthed revealing the preoccupation with the phallus,<ref name="Singley"/> also unearthing an 18-inch [[terracotta]] phallus protruding from what was believed to have been a bakery with the inscription, "Hie habitat felicitas" (here dwells happiness), and many Romans wore phallus [[amulet]]s to ward off the evil-eye.<ref name="Harris2007">{{cite book|last=Harris|first=Judith|title=Pompeii Awakened: A Story of Rediscovery|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8cmm4bvaVVYC&pg=PA120|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=15 June 2007|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-1-84511-241-7|page=120}}</ref><ref name="Guiley2008">{{cite book|last=Guiley|first=Rosemary|title=The Encyclopedia of Witches, Witchcraft and Wicca|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nDdcVt9-jnMC&pg=PA115|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=1 January 2008|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=978-1-4381-2684-5|page=115}}</ref>
Priapic worship amongst the women of Sicily continued into the 18th century; worshiping phallic votive objects and kissing such offerings before placing them upon the altar in the churches.<ref name="Singley"/> Fetishism with the phallus architecturally and in smaller implements was also exhibited by certain Christian sects in medieval times, such as the [[Manichaean]]s, and was connected with [[Sadomasochism|masochism]] and [[Sadistic personality disorder|sadism]], a form of religious flagellantism.<ref name="Bloch2003"/> Smaller phallic shaped monuments in the form of idols, even vases, rings, drinking vessels and jewellery have been well-documented and could be found within medieval churches of Ireland.<ref name="Bloch2003"/>
{{double image|right|Candi Sukuh.jpg|270|Candi Sukuh 2010 Bennylin 26.jpg|130|Left: The pyramid of [[Candi Sukuh]] of [[East Java]], [[Indonesia]]. Right: A graphic depiction of a phallus entering a vagina at the temple, one of many.}} In [[Hinduism]], the [[Hindu]] [[trimurthi]] represents [[Brahma]], the creator, [[Vishnu]], the preserver and [[Shiva]], the destroyer. Shiva, the main deity in India, is both destroyer and is stated to also include his role of creation; this creation role is represented by the phallic symbol, known as ''[[lingam]]'' in which form he is worshiped or in the form of male trinity of penis and two testicles.<ref name=" Wall 2001">{{cite book|last= Wall |first= Otto Augustus |title=Sex and Sex Worship (phallic Worship): A Scientific Treatise on Sex, Its Nature and Function, and Its Influence on Art, Science, Architecture, and Religion-with Special Reference to Sex Worship and Symbolism|url=https://books.google.com/?id=sfMaAAAAYAAJ&pg=PR14&lpg=PR14&dq=Phallic+architecture+in+India#v=onepage&q=Phallic%20architecture%20in%20India&f=false|year=1920|publisher= C.V. Mosby Company}}</ref> The ''linga'', or phallus, is a common feature of Hindu temples across India, engrained as reliefs or other forms. The [[Brihadeeswarar Temple]] of [[Tanjore]] in [[Tamil Nadu]], built during the [[Chola Dynasty]], is dedicated to Shiva, and features ''lingam'' between the cells; it is especially renowned for its "Hall of One Thousand Lingas".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Noble |first1=William A. |title=The Architecture and Organization of Kerala Style Hindu Temples |journal=Anthropos |date=1981 |volume=76 |issue=1/2 |pages=1–24 |jstor=40460291}}</ref>
In [[Indonesia]], the phallic [[lingam|''lingga'']] and feminine ''[[yoni]]'', remain common symbols of harmony. The [[Keraton Kasepuhan|Sultan's Palace of Kasepuhan]], in [[West Java]], has a number of ''lingga-yoni'' carvings along its walls. According to the Indonesian chronicles of the [[Babad Tanah Jawi]], Prince Puger gained the kingly power from [[God]], by ingesting sperm from the phallus of the already-dead [[Amangkurat II of Mataram|Sultan Amangkurat II of Mataram]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Moertono|first=Soemarsaid|title=State and Statecraft in Old Java: A Study of the Later Mataram Period, 16th to 19th Century|year=2009|publisher=Equinoc Publishing|isbn=9786028397438|pages=68}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Darmaputera|first=Eka|title=Pancasila and the search for identity and modernity in Indonesian society: a cultural and ethical analysis|year=1988|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004084223|pages=108–9}}</ref>
[[Candi Sukuh]] temple of Ngancar, [[East Java]], was built in the 10th century and is dedicated to Shiva. The temple has numerous reliefs graphically depicting sexuality and fertility including several stone depictions of a copulating penis and vagina.<ref name="KinneyKlokke2003">{{cite book|last1=Kinney|first1=Ann R.|last2=Klokke|first2=Marijke J.|last3=Kieven|first3=Lydia|title=Worshiping Siva and Buddha: The Temple Art of East Java|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sfa2FiIERLYC&pg=PA268|accessdate=29 September 2012|year=2003|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=978-0-8248-2779-3|page=268}}</ref> It consists of a pyramid with reliefs and statues at the front. Among them is a male statue clutching his penis, with three [[tortoise]]s with flattened shells.<ref name="KinneyKlokke2003"/> The temple once had a striking 1.82 metre (5'11.5 ft) representation of ''lingga'' with four testicles; this is now housed in the [[National Museum of Indonesia]]. Phallic references were also made in [[Khmer architecture]] in [[Cambodia]], and several Khmer temples depict the phallus in reliefs.
In Africa, Ancient [[Mali]]ans, particularly the royals of [[Djenne]], decorated their palaces with phallus like piers and columns at the entrance of their palaces and decorated the walls with phallus motifs.<ref name="BloomBlair2009">{{cite book|last1=Bloom|first1=Jonathan|last2=Blair|first2=Sheila|title=The Grove Encyclopedia of Islamic Art & Architecture: Three-volume set|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=un4WcfEASZwC&pg=PA24|accessdate=12 September 2012|date=23 March 2009|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-530991-1|page=24}}</ref> Similar features can be seen on the pillars of many temples across Africa, often interpreted by western scholars to be phallic symbols, but may often be more subtle and subject to varying interpretations.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Prussin |first1=Labelle |title=An Introduction to Indigenous African Architecture |journal=Journal of the Society of Architectural Historians |date=1974 |volume=33 |issue=3 |pages=183–205 |doi=10.2307/988854 |jstor=988854 |url=http://www.arch.mcgill.ca/prof/sijpkes/arch528/fall2001/lecture3/african-architecture.pdf}}</ref> Like the ancient Egyptian pharaohs, [[Aksum]]ite kings built temples with phallic pillars in ancient Ethiopian cities such as [[Konsu]], and monolithic pillars with phallic representation have also been discovered in [[Madagascar]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gensheimer |first1=Thomas R. |title=''Research Notes:'' Monumental Tomb Architecture of the Medieval Swahili Coast |journal=Buildings & Landscapes: Journal of the Vernacular Architecture Forum |date=2012 |volume=19 |issue=1 |pages=107–114 |doi=10.1353/bdl.2012.0002 |jstor=988854}}</ref> In ancient [[Maya civilization|Maya]], phallic architecture was rare but [[Uxmal]] in particular has a considerable number of phallus-like architectural pieces. It contains a temple known as the Temple of the Phallis and phallic sculptures and motifs.<ref name="Sharer1994">{{cite book|last=Sharer|first=Robert|title=The Ancient Maya: Fifth Edition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c65_g571LyAC&pg=PA376|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=1 November 1994|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0-8047-2130-1|page=376}}</ref>
===Modern=== [[File:Dionysos Theatre, Athens.jpg|thumb|300px|The [[Dionysus]] Theatre of [[Athens]]. Phallic columns can still be seen of the ruined Ancient Greek theatre.]] [[Claude Nicholas Ledoux]] was a major exponent of architectural development in the 17th century which "articulated across the tensions of form and ornament, symbol, and allegory, dogma, and fantasy", at a time when western society was oppressive and particularly sensitive to public displays of sexuality; blatant and graphic phallic architecture would have been considered an embarrassment and a shameful act.<ref name="Singley">{{cite journal |last1=Singley |first1=Paulette |title=The Anamorphic Phallus within Ledoux's Dismembered Plan of Chaux |journal=Journal of Architectural Education |date=1993 |volume=46 |issue=3 |pages=176–188 |doi=10.2307/1425159 |jstor=1425159}}</ref> In his initial draft for the House of Pleasure in Chaux (a proposed ideal city, near the [[Forest of Chaux]]), Ledoux drew upon allegorical ideas in his design with the union of man and woman, a physiological interpretation of intercourse and penetration. Private bedrooms were designed to "thrust out from the circular ring of the building, metaphorically representing penetration, the circular ring representing the vaginal passage and womb of the female.<ref name="Singley"/>
The second revised design is said to "subliminate both elevated site and female gender" with a "lonely phallus", without the original planned animated circular ring representing the female reproductive organs.<ref name="Singley"/> Ledoux drew upon phallic and sexually charged inspiration in other buildings which he designed. His design of Besançon Theatre for instance was fueled by the exigencies of prostitution and ancient sexual ritual.<ref name="Singley"/> However, in comparison to the likes of [[Jean-Jacques Lequeu]], who gained notoriety for his pornographic architectural concoctions, Ledoux's architectural inspiration was relatively mild, and he is said to have omitted towers from his designs on occasion as he was aware that they would be frowned upon shamefully by general society as a too obvious representation of the phallus; Ledoux's "missing erection" is explained to this effect in Jacques Lecan's ''Significance of the Missing Phalus''.<ref name="Singley"/>
According to [[Oscar Reutersvärd]], the interest in neoclassical architecture in the 18th century was synonymous with and motivated by a similar interest in masculine virility.<ref name="Singley"/> Works such as [[Francesco Colonna]]'s ''[[Hypnerotomachia Poliphili]]'' (1467) and [[Giovanni Battista Piranesi]]'s ''[[Campo Marzio]]'' (1762) show profoundly the ancient influence of phallic architecture in design and worship, and contain numerous illustrations of Priapic temples and architecture.<ref name="Singley"/> Piranesi in particular is said to have offered a "prototype for the mysterious architecture of phallic worship that more closely resembles the houses of pleasure" in his etchings.<ref name="Singley"/>
He located two designs for the Bustum Caesaris Augusti, concluding that they were based upon sexual ritual, with "two phallic plans penetrating the semicircular cubicula". Piranesi believed that the purpose of the phallic designs were to celebrate virility and male regenerative power.<ref name="Singley"/> Other commentators such as [[Carl August Ehrensvärd]] also provided illustrations and analysis of Priapic temples and the meaning of phallic architecture.<ref name="Singley"/> A work of note to this effect is ''Neoclassical Temple of Virility and the Buildings with a Phallic Shaped Plan'' (1977) of the Institute for Art History of the [[University of Lund]], [[Sweden]].<ref name="Singley"/>
In America, especially in [[Chicago]] and [[New York City|New York]], and numerous other global cities, high rise skyscrapers of phallic shape grew up in the 20th century. [[Le Corbusier]], the famous architect, propagated it in Europe in place of traditional decorative architecture. Similar futuristic developments took place in Italy with the initiative of Sant’Elia, symbolizing the triumph of man. Yet unlike those of ancient times which were blatant architectural representations of the phallus, in the West in modern times "shrines to the phallus" are more subtle, and may often be subject to interpretation as such; very few architects have specifically admitted the human phallus as a source for their architectural creation.<ref name="Bakos2011">{{cite book|last=Bakos|first=Susan Crain|title=Daily Sex Bible: Inspirations and Techniques for the Best Year of Sex Ever|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iyDbDGsmqlAC&pg=PA51|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=1 January 2011|publisher=Quiver|isbn=978-1-59233-447-6|page=51}}</ref> The [[Italian Fascism|Italian Fascists]] were cited as having an obsession with phallic architecture which was rigid and impermeable.<ref name="Mississippi1994">{{cite book|author=University of Mississippi|title=Faulkner and Psychology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CcQZ26PM-g8C&pg=PA44|accessdate=12 September 2012|year=1994|publisher=Univ. Press of Mississippi|isbn=978-0-87805-743-6|page=44}}</ref> In the last few decades the high-rise phallic skyscraper has been a symbol of government quest for economic power in China, Hong Kong and South Korea and the other [[ASEAN]]/[[Pacific Rim]] nations. China fuels billions of dollars annually into high-rise office and residential buildings with the aim of increasing GDP, at a rate far greater than they can be occupied.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/20/business/global/20ghost.html?pagewanted=all | publisher=''[[New York Times]]'' | first=David | last=Barboza | title=A New Chinese City, With Everything but People |date=20 October 2010 }}</ref>
==Symbolism== {{double image|right|Place vendome jms.jpg| 185|Penis park korea2.jpg|208|Left: [[Vendome Column]], [[Paris]]. Right: One of the many penis statues of [[Haesindang Park]] (Penis Park), [[South Korea]].}} In art and architecture, acutely vertical buildings are often seen as a symbol of masculinity and horizontal buildings are seen as more feminine.<ref name="Lin2010">{{cite book|last=Lin|first=Xiaoping|title=Children of Marx and Coca-Cola: Chinese Avant-Garde Art and Independent Cinema|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vJrEf1owrjoC&pg=PA46|accessdate=12 September 2012|date=1 January 2010|publisher=University of Hawaii Press|isbn=978-0-8248-3336-7|page=46}}</ref><ref name="Rendell1999">{{cite book|last=Rendell|first=Jane|title=Gender Space Architecture: An Interdisciplinary Introduction|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fkKVXyeZ0A0C&pg=PA229|accessdate=12 September 2012|date=11 November 1999|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-415-17253-0|page=229}}</ref> The terms "phallic verticality", "phallic erectility" and "phallic brutality" have been referred to by architectural theorists, including the likes of French sociologist [[Henri Lefebvre]], who argued that buildings of phallic architectural type metaphorically symbolize "force, male fertility, masculine violence".<ref name="Lin2010"/><ref name="Hays2000"/> Phallic erectility "bestows a special status on the perpendicular, proclaiming phallocracy as the orientation of space" while phallic brutality "does not remain abstract, for it is the brutality of political power."<ref name="Hays2000">{{cite book|last=Hays|first=K. Michael|title=Architecture Theory since 1968|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4JQKFqe9m-wC&pg=PA187|accessdate=12 September 2012|date=28 February 2000|publisher=MIT Press|isbn=978-0-262-58188-2|page=187}}</ref>
Lefebvre conducted considerable research into the meaning of high-rise buildings.<ref name="Lin2010"/> He said "The arrogant verticality of skyscrapers, and especially of public and state buildings, introduces a phallic or more precisely a phallocratic element into the visual realm; the purpose of this display, of this need to impress, is to convey an impression of authority to each spectator. Verticality and great height have ever been the spatial expression of potentially violent power."<ref name="Lin2010"/> [[Sigmund Freud]] metaphorically drew a comparison between "high achievement and the acquisition of wealth as building monuments to our penises."<ref name="Publishing1995">{{cite book|title=The Advocate|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h2QEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA56|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=22 August 1995|publisher=Here Publishing|page=56|issn=0001-8996}}</ref>
In the 19th century, [[Thomas Mical]] argues that surrealists "capitalized on the phallic symbolism of monuments such as the ancient Egyptian obelisk from Luxor in the [[Place de la Concorde]] or the [[Vendome Column]]" by "supplementing these phallic structures with female counterparts".<ref name="Mical2004">{{cite book|last=Mical|first=Thomas|title=Surrealism and Architecture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AR6bNi55BgUC&pg=PA200|accessdate=12 September 2012|date=17 December 2004|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-415-32520-2|page=200}}</ref> [[Jules Breton]] for example suggested moving the obelisk to [[La Villette abattoir]] and designing a large gloved hand of a woman holding the obelisk in a suggestive manner, and adapting the Vendome into a factory chimney with a nude woman climbing it.<ref name="Mical2004"/> [[Auguste Bartholdi]]'s 1870 monument ''Defense of Paris'' for instance, a commemoration of [[Leon Gambetta]]'s escape from Paris in balloon during the [[Franco-Prussian War]], was also subject to debate amongst Parisian artists of the late 19th century as they believed it resembled a testicle.<ref name="Mical2004"/> [[Arthur Harfaux]] proposed turning the monument into "an enormous sex, the balloon forming a testicle and the phallus being horizontal", while Breton proposed turning it into copulating genitals, adding a twin balloon to form two testicles.<ref name="Mical2004"/>
[[File:Jules Breton.jpg|thumb|[[Jules Breton]] (1827–1906), a French realist artist who was keen to advocate phallic architecture in late 19th century Paris.]] Contemporary scholars in architectural criticism have investigated the relationship between architecture and the body, sexuality, sex, power, and place.<ref name="Ahrentzen">{{cite journal |last1=Ahrentzen |first1=Sherry |last2=Anthony |first2=Kathryn H. |title=Sex, Stars, and Studios: A Look at Gendered Educational Practices in Architecture |journal=Journal of Architectural Education |date=1993 |volume=47 |issue=1 |pages=11–29 |doi=10.2307/1425224 |jstor=1425224 |hdl=2142/25089 |hdl-access=free|url=https://www.ideals.illinois.edu/bitstream/handle/2142/25089/Sex%2C%20Stars%2C%20and%20Studios-%20A%20Look%20at%20Gendered%20Educational%20Practices%20in%20Architecture.pdf?sequence=2&isAllowed=y}}</ref> Feminists in particular, such as [[Margrit Kennedy]], perceive high-rise phallic-like buildings on the urban landscape as "phallic symbols of male domination, power and rational instrumentality."<ref name="Transition">{{cite book|title=Transition|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-LZUAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=16 September 2012|year=1988|publisher=Transition Pub.,.|page=41}}</ref> [[Esther M. K. Cheung]] believes the form of monumental high-rise building which grew up in 20th century America can "be read as a phallic symbol of power".<ref name="Cheung2009">{{cite book|last=Cheung|first=Esther M. K.|title=Fruit Chan's Made in Hong Kong|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-kSYYkAcs4AC&pg=PA110|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=15 August 2009|publisher=Hong Kong University Press|isbn=978-962-209-977-7|page=110}}</ref> The present trend symbolises "Science and technology over nature, incorporating all the maleness which that with sci-fi utopias."<ref name=" Greed, 1994">{{cite book|last= Greed |first= Clara H.| title= Women and Planning: Creating Gendered Realities |url= https://books.google.com/?id=nRY3AQAAIAAJ&q=Phallic+architecture+in+modern+buildings&dq=Phallic+architecture+in+modern+buildings|year=1994|publisher= Taylor & Francis |isbn= 9780415079815|pages =119–120}}</ref> [[Elizabeth Grosz]], however, offers a counter argument to phallocentrism in urban design theories, saying "not so much the dominance of the phallus as the pervasive unacknowledged use of the male or masculine to represent the human. The problem, then, is not so much to eliminate as to reveal the masculinity inherent in the notion of the universal, the generic human, or the unspecified subject."<ref name="Ahrentzen"/> [[Marc C. Taylor]] discusses phallic architecture and what makes a building masculine or feminine in his book ''Disfiguring: Art, Architecture, Religion''.<ref name="Lin2010"/>
===Symbols and shrines=== [[File:Mara-kannnon2017-05.jpg|thumb|[[:ja:麻羅観音|Marakannnon(JAPAN)]]]] During the modern era, many sculptors have created some public phallic works of art, with varying degrees of subtlety. One of these examples may be the statue in honor to the [[Carnation Revolution]] on the top of a hill in [[Lisbon]], [[Portugal]] by the sculptor [[João Cutileiro]].<ref>{{cite journal | author=Teixeira, José | title=Escultura pública em Portugal : monumentos, heróis e mitos (séc. XX) | publisher=UTL |url=http://repositorio.ul.pt/handle/10451/661}}</ref> Perhaps the greatest example of a phallic cemetery is the [[Khalid Nabi Cemetery]] in hills of northeastern [[Iran]] near the border with [[Turkmenistan]], roughly {{convert|40|miles}} northeast of [[Gonbad-e Kavous]].<ref name="IGP">{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/middle-east/101111/iran-tourism-penis-tombstones|title=In Iran, tombstones shaped like penises delight tourists|publisher=''Iran GlobalPost''|date=12 November 2010|accessdate=17 September 2012}}</ref> According to a popular belief, the cemetery house the tomb of a pre-Islamic [[prophet]], Khalid Nabi, who was born 40 years prior to the birth of [[Muhammad]], in c. 530.<ref name="IGP"/> The ancient graveyard contains some 600 tombstones of unknown origin, many of which are clear representations of the phallus; from a distance they resemble stone pegs.<ref name="IGP"/>
{{double image|right|Chao Mae Tuptim-006.jpg|224|Kharkhorin Rock.jpg|200|Left: [[Chao Mae Tuptim]], [[Bangkok]], [[Thailand]]. Right: A smaller version of the [[Kharkarin Rock]], near [[Erdene Zuu Monastery]], [[Mongolia]].}} Phallic shrines are common in Far East Asia, especially in Buddhist parts of Korea and Japan where they are seen as symbols of fertility or prowess.<ref name="Nemeth1987"/> In [[Dragon Pool Temple]] in [[Jeju City]], there is a phallic shrine which is visited by female pilgrims who come to worship it for its perceived fertility blessings. The phallic stone is made from granite, quite small in size and white and was reportedly found in a field nearby by a farmer.<ref name="Nemeth1987">{{cite book|last=Nemeth|first=David J.|title=The Architecture of Ideology: Neo-Confucian Imprinting on Cheju Island, Korea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Za4my8EshDEC&pg=PA197|accessdate=12 September 2012|date=4 September 1987|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-09713-1|page=197}}</ref>
In Thailand, the phallus is also considered to be a symbol of good luck and representative of fertility. There are numerous shrines in the country featuring phallic architecture. [[Chao Mae Tuptim]] shrine in [[Bangkok]], behind the [[Swissôtel Bangkok]] hotel has over a hundred colored circumcised wooden penis statues of all shapes and sizes which are said to possess special cosmic powers and endow good fortune and fertility on anybody coming into contact with them.<ref name="Guelden1995">{{cite book|last=Guelden|first=Marlane|title=Thailand into the Spirit World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=orTXAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=29 September 2012|year=1995|publisher=Times Editions|page=75}}</ref><ref name="HoskinInvernizzi1990">{{cite book|last1=Hoskin|first1=John|last2=Invernizzi|first2=Luca|title=Bangkok|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QyMKAQAAMAAJ|accessdate=29 September 2012|year=1990|publisher=Times Editions|isbn=978-1-55650-271-2|page=88}}</ref>
Near [[Erdene Zuu Monastery]] in [[Övörkhangai Province]] of [[Mongolia]] is [[Kharkhorin Rock]] which contains a massive statue of a penis raised on a platform on the steppe. The statue has dual functions; primarily it is a reminder to the monks to remain celibate, but it is also a symbol of fertility and human life.<ref name="Kohn2008">{{cite book|last=Kohn|first=Michael|title=Mongolia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7JVGCF-MPB0C&pg=PA123|accessdate=29 September 2012|date=1 May 2008|publisher=Lonely Planet|isbn=978-1-74104-578-9|page=123}}</ref> A smaller statue of a phallus is nearer the monastery. [[Haesindang Park]] (also known as "Penis Park") in [[Gangwon-do (South Korea)|Gangwon Province]] of [[South Korea]], located about {{convert|20|km}} south of [[Samcheok]], is a nature park which contains a number of erect statues. A tragic legend shrouds them in that a virgin was once swept out to sea and drowned, unable to be saved by her lover. The townspeople were devastated and helpless, and a curse appeared to have been cast over them, ruining the local fishing industry. One day, a local fisherman relieved himself in the sea and miraculously the fishing industry revived. He discovered that her restless spirit could be appeased in such a manner, so the townsfolk compensated for the woman's inability to consummate beyond the grave by placing sexually potent phallic statues in view of the shore.<ref name="BalasingamchowRichmond2010">{{cite book|last1=Balasingamchow|first1=Yu-Mei|last2=Richmond|first2=Simon|last3=Soriano|first3=Cesar G.|author4=Whyte, Rob |title=Korea|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h9-DOFiUI5oC&pg=PA194|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=1 May 2010|publisher=Lonely Planet|isbn=978-1-74104-831-5|page=194}}</ref> The statues range in size and styles; some have faces on them and are more animated in appearance and more colorful, but others are exact depictions of the human penis.
In some Asian countries such as [[Bhutan]], many have a belief that a phallus brings good luck and drives away evil spirits. [[Phallus paintings in Bhutan|Phallus symbols are routinely painted outside walls of the new houses]] and carved wooden phalluses are hung (sometimes crossed by a design of sword or dagger) outside, on the eves of the new homes, at the four corners.<ref name="Brown">{{cite book |last=Brown |first=Lindsey |first2=Bradley |last2=Mayhew |first3=Stan |last3=Armington |first4=Richard |last4=Whitecross |title=Bhutan |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s-L8NUlW_QgC&printsec=frontcover |accessdate=12 September 2012 |publisher=Penguin |year=2009 |isbn=1-74059-529-7 |pages=13, 78, 79, 144}}</ref> On a road drive from [[Paro airport]] to [[Thimphu]] explicit paintings of phalluses are a common sight on the white-washed walls of homes, shops and eateries.<ref name="Brown"/> In the [[Chimi Lhakhang]] monastery, the shrine dedicated to Drupka Kinley, several wooden penises are used to bless people who visit the monastery on pilgrimage seeking blessings to bear a child or for welfare of their children. The glaringly displayed phallus in the monastery is a brown wooden piece with a silver handle, a religious relic considered to possess divine powers and hence used for blessing the spiritually oriented people. It is also said to prevent quarrels among family members in the houses which are painted with these symbols.<ref name="Brown"/>
==Buildings and structures== {{double image|right|Empire State Building from the Top of the Rock.jpg|200|Leaning tower of pisa 2.jpg|200|Left: [[Empire State Building]], [[New York City]]. Right: The [[Leaning Tower of Pisa]]}}
===Empire State Building=== The 102-story [[Empire State Building]], located in [[Midtown Manhattan]], [[New York City]], at the intersection of [[Fifth Avenue (Manhattan)|Fifth Avenue]] and [[34th Street (Manhattan)|West 34th Street]], is one of the world's most famous landmarks, and is generally thought of as an American [[cultural icon]]. Cited by Valerie Briginshaw as a symbol of American pride and "the ultimate sign of American phallic power", it was inaugurated on 31 May 1931.<ref name="Briginshaw2001">{{cite book|last=Briginshaw|first=Valerie|title=Dance, Space and Subjectivity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mVC_M88kLlIC&pg=PA130|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=12 October 2001|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|isbn=978-0-333-91973-6|page=130}}</ref><ref name="Douglas2004"/>
Designed in the [[Art Deco]] style, it has a roof height of 1,250 feet (381 meters), and with its [[antenna tower|antenna]] spire included, it stands a total of 1,454 ft (443.2 m) high. It stood as the [[List of tallest buildings and structures in the world|world's tallest building]] for 40 years, from its completion in 1931 until construction of the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]]'s North Tower was completed in 1972. After the World Trade Center was destroyed on [[September 11 attacks|September 11, 2001]], it remained the tallest building in New York City for 13 years until the [[One World Trade Center]] was completed. Numerous people have mentioned its similarities in appearance to the phallus, with its "tall and glinting" towers.<ref name="Douglas2004">{{cite book|last=Douglas|first=George H.|title=Skyscrapers: A Social History Of The Very Tall Building In America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IxDUUqut-XkC&pg=PA107|accessdate=17 September 2012|year=2004|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-2030-8|page=107}}</ref><ref name="Harris2011">{{cite book|last=Harris|first=Scott Jordan|title=World Film Locations: New York|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wyFaitD4rpcC&pg=PA32|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=15 August 2011|publisher=Intellect Books|isbn=978-1-84150-482-7|page=32}}</ref><ref name="Stein2001">{{cite book|last=Stein|first=Herbert|title=Double Feature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZR9pr9XW-rEC&pg=PA51|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=1 October 2001|publisher=E-reads/E-rights|isbn=978-0-7592-3192-4|page=51}}</ref>
===Leaning Tower of Pisa=== The [[Leaning Tower of Pisa]] in [[Pisa]], [[Italy]], dating from around 1173, has long suffered from structural problems. The tower is eight stories high at {{Convert|55.86|m|ft}} and before restoration work from 1990 leaned 5.5 degrees. It currently leans about 4 degrees but due to foundation problems it continues to sink about 1mm annually. The resemblance of the tower to a penis has seen the "Leaning Tower of Pisa" became a sexual slang term for a half erect penis.<ref name="Lloyd2010">{{cite book|last=Lloyd|first=Shannon|title=Rita and the Kids Next Door|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fXeFVQWC12UC&pg=PA109|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=June 2010|publisher=Olympia Press|isbn=978-1-60872-284-6|page=109}}</ref> Local retailers have attempted to capitalize on the tower as a phallic architectural piece by making souvenirs featuring underwear with the tower resembling a penis. The Catholic Church denounced the promotion of the tower in such a manner as showing "a complete lack of respect" and a "disgrace" and retailers can now be fined up to €500 for selling items promoting the tower as a penis.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/travel/article-2022760/Pisas-mayor-bans-erotic-tourist-souvenirs.html#ixzz26ejOacvy |title=Pisa's Mayor vows to ban 'trashy' erotic tourist souvenirs|publisher=''[[Daily Mail]]''|accessdate=5 October 2011|location=London|date=5 August 2011}}</ref>
===Nelson's Column===
[[Nelson's Column]], a monument to Admiral [[Horatio Nelson]], was erected by a grateful nation between 1840 and 1843 to commemorate Nelson's victory at the [[Battle of Trafalgar]]. However the Nelson Memorial Committee ran out of money, having only raised £20,485 in public subscriptions.<ref name=NelsonHansard>Hansards Parliamentary Debates, Vol. CXLIV, p.1220.</ref> The column is Corinthian with a granite shaft.<ref name=Nelson>{{cite journal |year=1839 |title=The Selected Design for the Nelson Testimonial |journal= The Art Union |volume=1 |issue= |page=100 |publisher= |doi= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H7TlAAAAMAAJ&printsec=frontcover&dq=art+journal+1839#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate= 30 May 2011}}, p.100</ref> In his poem ''A Ballad of the Good Lord Nelson'', [[Lawrence Durrell]] included the multiply allusive lines "Now stiff on a pillar with a phallic air/Nelson [[stylites]] in Trafalgar Square/Reminds the British what once they were."<ref>{{cite book | title=Selected Poems 1935-1963 | publisher=Faber | last=Durrell |first=Lawrence | authorlink=Lawrence Durrell |section=A Ballad of the Good Lord Nelson | year=1964 | pages=84}}</ref>
===Colonna Mediterranea=== [[File:Colonna_Mediterranea.jpeg|thumb|right|200px|[[Colonna Mediterranea]] in [[Luqa]], [[Malta]]]] [[Colonna Mediterranea]] is a monumental column in [[Luqa]], [[Malta]]. It has been described by its artist Paul Vella Critien as an "Egyptian symbol". However at a glance it could be observed to look similar to a large [[penile]], and therefor was largely described to be a "phallic monument". The monument has managed to attract several international media coverage in specific before and during the visit of [[Pope Benedict XVI]] to Malta as the pope mobile, carrying the papacy, had been planned and passed by it. Similarly the same artist has created another monumental column, the [[Kolonna Eterna]], which was also described as being phallic by critics.<ref>[http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20100413/local/luqas-monument-makes-international-headlines.302567 "Luqa's monument makes international headlines"], [[Times of Malta]], 2010.</ref><ref>Stanglin Douglas (2010), [http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2010/04/maltese-town-demands-removal-of-phallic-monument-before-popes-visit/1#.Vm2Y4np4WrU "Maltese town demands removal of 'phallic' monument before pope's visit"], One Dead Line.</ref><ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8617305.stm "'Phallic' art sparks row ahead of Pope's Malta visit"], [[BBC]], 2010.</ref><ref>Peregin Christian (2010), [http://www.timesofmalta.com/articles/view/20100413/local/dont-let-pope-benedict-see-monument-luqa-council.302476 "'Don't let Pope Benedict see monument' - Luqa council"], [[Times of Malta]].</ref>
===Obelisk of Luxor=== The [[Obelisk of Luxor]], which stands in the [[Place de la Concorde]] of [[Paris]], France, was given to the French by the Egyptians in the 1800s. The 23-meter (75-foot) obelisk originally stood at the front of [[Luxor Temple]], honoring [[Ramses II]], pharaoh of the [[Nineteenth Dynasty of Egypt]]. According to [[Michael D. Garval]], the French perceived the obelisk as "prodigiously phallic" from the moment it arrived.<ref name="Garval2004">{{cite book|last=Garval|first=Michael D.|title="A Dream of Stone": Fame, Vision, and Monumentality in Nineteenth-Century French Literary Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jadTA5yudTcC&pg=PA74|accessdate=16 September 2012|year=2004|publisher=University of Delaware Press|isbn=978-0-87413-862-7|page=74}}</ref>
===Oriental Pearl TV Tower=== The [[Oriental Pearl TV Tower]], located in [[Pudong Park]] in [[Lujiazui]], [[Shanghai]], [[China]], is the world’s third tallest TV and radio tower at {{Convert|468|m|ft}}, the tallest such building in [[Asia]]. The tower houses restaurants, theaters, a conference hall, and a hotel and is a significant tourist attraction in the city. The tower has been met a mixed reception, however. ''[[The New York Times]]'' described it as a "great phallic monster of truly monumental ugliness, a bit like an enormous asparagus with a silver ball on top."<ref name="The New York Times magazine">{{cite book|title=The New York Times magazine|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eIA7AQAAIAAJ|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=January 1996|publisher=The New York Times.|page=110}}</ref> The long steel column tower is considered by some to be proof of the city's phallic worship, and that such skyscrapers indicative of wealth are an increasing aphrodisiac of the materialist in Chinese cities.<ref name="Ong2006">{{cite book|last=Ong|first=Aihwa|title=Neoliberalism as Exception: Mutations in Citizenship and Sovereignty|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bVQJ0Pe2iQkC&pg=PA219|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=28 June 2006|publisher=Duke University Press|isbn=978-0-8223-3748-5|page=219}}</ref>
===Burj Qatar===
The [[Doha_Tower|Burj Qatar]] was designed by French architect [[Jean Nouvel]]. In 2004, the project was first called the "High Rise Office Building".<ref name="designbuild-network">{{cite web|work=Design Build Network|url=http://www.designbuild-network.com/projects/doha9highrisseoffice/|title=Doha 9 High Rise Office Tower, Qatar|accessdate=14 March 2013}}</ref> Following completion in 2012, it was originally called the "Burj Doha" by its owner, H. E. Sheikh [[Saud bin Muhammed Al Thani]]. The public has noted the building's "phallic form",<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/06/magazine/06nouvel.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0 The Contextualizer] By Arthur Lubow, NYT, April 6, 2008</ref><ref>[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/2/dd454d60-3563-11e0-aa6c-00144feabdc0.html Bridge in the Gulf] By Edwin Heathcote, Financial Times, February 11, 2011</ref> suggestive of what Nouvel calls a “fully assumed virility.”<ref>[http://www.vanityfair.com/online/beauty/2008/04/jean-nouvels-message-in-a-bottle Jean Nouvel's Message in a Bottle] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130415040229/http://www.vanityfair.com/online/beauty/2008/04/jean-nouvels-message-in-a-bottle |date=2013-04-15 }} By Julian Sancton, Vanity Fair, April 28, 2008</ref>
===State Capitol, Lincoln=== The [[Nebraska State Capitol|State Capitol]] building of [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] has been cited as the "apex" of phallic architecture.<ref name="CampbellAverbuck2008">{{cite book|last1=Campbell|first1=Jeff|last2=Averbuck|first2=Alexis|last3=Bao|first3=Sandra|author4=Bender, Andy |title=USA|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JwvE1F2zyXoC&pg=PA673|accessdate=12 September 2012|date=30 March 2008|publisher=Lonely Planet|isbn=978-1-74104-675-5|page=673}}</ref> At 15 stories and 400 feet (121 m) tall, it is the second-tallest U.S. statehouse, surpassed only by the 34-story [[Louisiana State Capitol]].<ref name="U.S. Sites and Symbols-Capital">{{cite book|title=U.S. Sites and Symbols-Capital|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=in0AjD93PJsC&pg=PA21|accessdate=17 September 2012|publisher=Weigl Publishers Inc.|isbn=978-1-60596-253-5|page=21}}</ref> It is the tallest building in Lincoln,<ref name="Meyer2010">{{cite book|last=Meyer|first=Diana Lambdin|title=Nebraska Off the Beaten Path, 7th: A Guide to Unique Places|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=94TGBJ6vfSsC&pg=PA10|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=1 July 2010|publisher=Globe Pequot|isbn=978-0-7627-5732-9|page=10}}</ref> the third-tallest in the state, and also the heaviest Capitol building in North America. The building was designed by [[Bertram Goodhue|Bertram Grosvenor Goodhue]], who drew upon [[Classical architecture|Classical]] and [[Gothic architecture|Gothic]] architectural traditions.<ref name="Marter2011">{{cite book|last=[[Joan Marter]]|first=|title=The Grove Encyclopedia of American Art|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sPGdBxzaWj0C&pg=RA1-PA355|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=20 January 2011|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-533579-8|page=355}}</ref> It was constructed between 1922 and 1932, of Indiana [[limestone]], with a golden dome.<ref name="Marter2011"/> The building is nicknamed "The Phallus of the Plains" for its phallus-like appearance.<ref name="MeetingGilland1984">{{cite book|last1=Gilland|first1=Wilmot G.|last2=Woodcock|first2=David|title=Architectural values and world issues: proceedings of the 71st Annual Meeting of the Association of Collegiate Schools of Architecture, 1983|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_WDzAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=17 September 2012|year=1984|publisher=Association of Collegiate Schools of Architecture|page=161}}</ref>
===30 St Mary Axe=== [[30 St Mary Axe]] opened in London in April 2004. Designed by [[Norman Foster]], the {{Convert|180|m|ft}} structure, London’s first environmentally sustainable tall building using recycled and recyclable materials, has been compared to the phallus and a [[gherkin]], which also is a slang term for "small penis"; its nicknames include Gherkin, the Erotic Gherkin, Towering Innuendo and the Crystal Phallus.<ref name="HerrleWegerhoff2008">{{cite book|last1=Herrle|first1=Peter|last2=Wegerhoff|first2=Erik|title=Architecture and Identity|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vs0Us4SSxUoC&pg=PA213|accessdate=16 September 2012|year=2008|publisher=LIT Verlag Münster|isbn=978-3-8258-1088-7|page=213}}</ref><ref name="Jarvis2009">{{cite book|last=Jarvis|first=Helen|title=Cities and Gender|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u3vSQnIbQekC&pg=PT34|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=10 June 2009|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-415-41569-9|page=34}}</ref><ref name=csrb/> Also likened to a "phallic fat cigar", the building has been cited as a "crude anatomical metaphor", yet has become one of the London's most iconic buildings.<ref name="Jarvis2009"/> ''[[Cabinet (magazine)|Cabinet]]'' voted it the "Best Uncircumcised Building in the World".<ref name=csrb>{{cite web|url=http://cabinetmagazine.org/events/phallic/uncircumcised.php|title=Best Uncircumcised Building in the World|publisher=''[[Cabinet (magazine)|Cabinet]]''|accessdate=16 September 2012}}</ref>
===Torre Agbar=== {{double image|right|Torre Agbar - Barcelona, Spain - Jan 2007.jpg|140|Washington Monument Dusk Jan 2006.jpg|245|Left: [[Torre Agbar]], [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]]. Right: [[Washington Monument]], [[Washington, D.C.]], United States}}
The [[Torre Agbar]] is a 38-story skyscraper located in the [[Plaça de les Glòries Catalanes]] of the [[Poblenou]] neighborhood of [[Barcelona]], [[Spain]]. Designed by [[Jean Nouvel]], it is named after its owners, the [[Grupo Agbar|Agbar Group]], a holding company whose interests include the Barcelona water company [[Aigües de Barcelona]]. An example of [[high-tech architecture]] in the city, its design combines a number of different architectural concepts, resulting in a striking structure built with [[reinforced concrete]], covered with a [[facade]] of [[glass]], and over 4,500 [[window]] openings cut out of the structural concrete. The building stands out on the skyline of Barcelona; it is the third tallest building in the city, standing at 144.44 m (473.88 ft), with an area of over 50,000 square metres, of which 30,000 are offices. 2,500 LED bulbs cause the tower to change color at night.<ref name="Whittaker2008">{{cite book|author=Andrew Whittaker|title=Spain: Be Fluent in Spanish Life and Culture|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2rZS8SWMroUC&pg=PT173|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=30 July 2008|publisher=Thorogood Publishing|isbn=978-1-85418-605-8|page=173}}</ref> It was officially opened by the King of Spain on 16 September 2005. Nouvel claims it to be inspired by a geyser and the nearby mountain of Montserrat, although he does note its phallic appearance.<ref name="MFPM2011">{{cite book|author=Michelin / MFPM|title=Spagna Nord|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jKZCklHcsJ8C&pg=PA257|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=1 January 2011|publisher=MICHELIN|isbn=978-2-06-715099-7|page=257}}</ref> Although many draw comparisons with the phallus, locals refer to the structure as ''el supositorio'' (the [[suppository]]), a drug delivery system that is inserted into the [[rectum]] or [[vagina]].<ref name="Whittaker2008" /><ref name="Lotus international">{{cite book|title=Lotus international|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w6ZUAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=17 September 2012|year=2004|publisher=Industrie Grafiche Editoriali}}</ref>
===Washington Monument=== The [[Washington Monument]] in [[Washington D.C.]] is often seen as a prime example of phallic architecture and American masculinity.<ref name="Boyle2009">{{cite book|last=Boyle|first=Brenda M.|title=Masculinity in Vietnam War Narratives: A Critical Study of Fiction, Films and Nonfiction Writings|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4ghHF8EngboC&pg=PA127|accessdate=16 September 2012|date=30 October 2009|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-4538-7|page=127}}</ref> The towering monument, made of [[marble]], [[granite]], and [[Gneiss|bluestone gneiss]], it is both the world's tallest stone structure and the world's tallest obelisk, standing {{convert|555|ft|5+1/8|in|m|3}} according to the [[National Park Service]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nps.gov/wamo/faqs.htm|title=Frequently Asked Questions about the Washington Monument|publisher=[[National Park Service]]|accessdate=16 September 2012}}</ref> Construction of the monument began in 1848, was halted from 1854 to 1877, and was completed in 1884. In a ''[[Magazine|Journal]]'' review, dated 17 October 1911, [[Arnold Bennett]] said of the monument, "Saw Washington monument. Phallic. Appalling. A national catastrophe – only equalled by the [[Albert Memorial]]. Tiny doll-like people waiting to go into it."<ref name="Yapp1983">{{cite book|last=Yapp|first=Peter|title=The Travellers' Dictionary of Quotation: Who Said What, about Where?|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vXsOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA970|accessdate=17 September 2012|year=1983|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-02760-1|pages=970–}}</ref> Dan Burstein says of it, "Speaking of sex symbols, there is no more phallic symbol in existence than the Washington Monument, and the Capitol dome can be viewed as breastlike."<ref name="Burstein2011">{{cite book|last=Burstein|first=Dan|title=Secrets of the Widow's Son|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PCVtrV8aIRYC&pg=PT69|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=20 October 2011|publisher=Orion|isbn=978-0-297-86491-2|page=69}}</ref> James Webb used a metaphor to praise the "uplift[ing]" power of the Washington Monument as a white phallus, "piercing the air like a bayonet".<ref name="Hagopian2011">{{cite book|last=Hagopian|first=Patrick|title=The Vietnam War in American Memory: Veterans, Memorials, and the Politics of Healing|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y1WAWa4L988C&pg=PA104|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=30 September 2011|publisher=Univ of Massachusetts Press|isbn=978-1-55849-902-7|page=104}}</ref> In the futuristic film ''[[Hardwired (film)|Hardwired]]'', set in the United States where everything noteworthy is commercialized, the Washington Monument is used as a giant [[Trojan (condoms)|Trojan]] condoms billboard.
===Ypsilanti Water Tower=== [[File:Ypsilanti Water Tower 2011.JPG|thumb|upright|right|[[Ypsilanti Water Tower]] in [[Ypsilanti, Michigan]], winner of the "Most Phallic Building contest"]] [[Ypsilanti Water Tower]] is a historic [[water tower]] in [[Ypsilanti, Michigan]], [[United States]], listed as a [[National Register of Historic Places]] building in 1981. The tower was designed by William R. Coats and constructed as part of an elaborate city waterworks project that began in 1889.<ref name="Ashlee2005">{{cite book|last=Ashlee|first=Laura Rose|title=Traveling Through Time: A Guide to Michigan's Historical Markers|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xd-mh9r0zEkC&pg=PA444|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=27 May 2005|publisher=University of Michigan Press|isbn=978-0-472-03066-8|page=444}}</ref> Located on the highest point in Ypsilanti, the tower was completed in 1890 at a cost of $21,435.63. Today the tower is frequently joked about for its phallic shape and has earned the nickname "Brick Dick".<ref name="Buhk2011">{{cite book|last=Buhk|first=Tobin T.|title=True Crime: Michigan: The State's Most Notorious Criminal Cases|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NN-tA-cUerIC&pg=PA91|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=7 June 2011|publisher=Stackpole Books|isbn=978-0-8117-0713-8|page=91}}</ref><ref name="Feldman2002">{{cite book|last=Feldman|first=Elliot|title=Sitting Shiva: A Novel|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K52v2XCAOKoC|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=December 2002|publisher=Foxrock Books|isbn=978-0-9643740-6-5|page=160}}</ref>
It has become a well-known landmark in Ypsilanti, and due to the building's shape and location, the tower is frequently used by residents as a point for providing directions for visitors and residents. [[Iggy Pop]] said of it in a 1996 interview, "The most famous thing in Ypsilanti is this water tower made out of brick, about 175 years old. It looks like this big penis."<ref name="LLC1996">{{cite book|title=SPIN|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SXQ6nPE3H9wC&pg=PA85|accessdate=17 September 2012|date=May 1996|publisher=SPIN Media LLC|page=85|issn=0886-3032}}</ref>
The World's [[Most Phallic Building contest]] was a contest held in 2003 by ''[[Cabinet (magazine)|Cabinet]]'' magazine to find the building which most resembled a human phallus.<ref>{{cite news |first=Lisa |last=Gutierrez |title=Another claim to fame for Liberty Memorial |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=KC&p_theme=kc&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0FFE6184248A5271&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |publisher=''[[Kansas City Star]]'' |date=29 December 2003}}</ref> The contest originated when writer [[Jonathan Ames]] drew the ire of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' readers by claiming, in a diary that was later published in his book ''I Love You More Than You Know'',<ref>{{cite news |first=Brendan |last=Halpin |title=Delightful essays of life's ups, downs in 'I Love You'; I Love You More Than You Know |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/990634401.html?dids=990634401:990634401&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Feb+21%2C+2006&author=Brendan+Halpin&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=BOOK+REVIEW%3B+Delightful+essays+of+life's+ups%2C+downs+in+%60I+Love+You'%3B+I+Love+You+More+Than+You+Know+Essays+Jonathan+Ames+Black+Cat%3A+270+pp.%2C+%2413+paper&pqatl=google |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=21 February 2006 |accessdate=16 September 2012 }}</ref> that the [[Williamsburgh Savings Bank Tower|Williamsburg Bank Building]] in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], was the world's most phallic. This led Cabinet magazine to initiate a search of its own to find which building was truly the "world's most phallic".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.forgotten-ny.com/STREET%20SCENES/willie/willie.html |title=Williamsburg Bank? |work=Forgotten-ny.com |accessdate=16 September 2012}}</ref> Cities and readers subsequently poured in their views and staked their claims to the magazine's editors. After months of entries and discussion, the Ypsilanti Water Tower was announced as the winner,<ref>{{cite news |title=A the awards: the 9 most remarkable things in culture this month.(man at his best) |url=http://www.accessmylibrary.com/coms2/summary_0286-19676527_ITM |work=[[Esquire (magazine)|Esquire]] |date=1 January 2004 |accessdate=16 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cabinetmagazine.org/phallic/winner.php |title=Cabinet Magazine Winner |work=[[Cabinet (magazine)|Cabinet]] |accessdate=16 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071002203209/http://www.cabinetmagazine.org/phallic/winner.php |archivedate=2 October 2007 |df= }}</ref> although the winner of a readers' poll was the [[Florida State Capitol]] building in [[Tallahassee]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Dan |last=Harrison |title=Site of the week |url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/11/05/1067989605047.html |work=[[The Age]] |date=6 November 2003|accessdate=16 September 2012 |location=Melbourne}}</ref> Another notable nominee was the Torre Agbar of Barcelona.<ref>{{cite book |title=High Society: Contemporary Highrise Architecture and the International Highrise Award 2006 |last= Gräwe |first=Christina |author2=Schmal, Peter Cachola |year=2007 |publisher=Jovis |isbn=3-936314-77-2 |pages=Dust jacket |url=https://books.google.com/?id=NQ2AAAAACAAJ&dq=%22Most+Phallic+Building%22}}</ref>
===Christian Science Church, Dixon, Illinois=== The [[Christian Science]] Dixon church in [[Dixon, Illinois]] strongly resembles a penis when viewed from the air.The church, however, claims it was tastefully designed around an old oak tree and declared that "We didn’t design it to be seen as what they’re seeing. And we didn’t design it to be seen from above."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/plans-change-shape-church-penis-article-1.1513939#ixzz2kSJGUMEk|title=No plans to change shape of Illinois church that looks like penis from the sky, officials say|publisher=''New York Daily News''|accessdate=12 November 2013}}</ref>
{{double image|right|Hyde Park Obelisk 1.jpg|200|Hyde Park Obelisk Condom.jpg|180|Left: [[Hyde Park Obelisk]], [[Sydney]]. Right: Giant condom covering the Obelisk in November 2014}}
===Hyde Park, Hyde, Greater Manchester=== In 2012, a beehive metal sculpture by [[Thompson Dagnall]] in [[Hyde, Greater Manchester]], was criticized by the council for installment adjacent to the children’s play area in Hyde park for looking too rude and phallic. Although Dagnall was paid £3,500 a week for his efforts, council workers modified the structure by stumping it and moved it to another part of the park.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/manchestereveningnews/news/s/1489633_beehive-sculpture-in-hyde-park-is-taken-down-for-being-too-phallic|title=Beehive sculpture in Hyde park is taken down for being ‘too phallic’|publisher=''[[Manchester Evening News]]''|date=28 March 2012|accessdate=16 September 2012}}</ref>
===''People's Daily'' Tower=== A new headquarters for the ''[[People's Daily]]'' newspaper has been under construction {{As of|2013|5|alt=since 2013}} and is slated for completion in 2014. In May 2013, China attempted to censor jokes about its phallic shape.<ref>Jennifer Wadsworth. "[http://blog.sfgate.com/hottopics/2013/05/03/china-tries-fails-to-censor-jokes-about-penis-shaped-skyscraper/ China tries, fails, to censor jokes about penis-shaped skyscraper]". ''SFGate'', 3 May 2013. Accessed 12 May 2013.</ref><ref>Alexander Abad-Santos. "[http://www.theatlanticwire.com/global/2013/05/peoples-daily-building-china-censorship/64845/ China Is Censoring Jokes About Its Propaganda Machine's Penis-Shaped HQ]". ''The Atlantic Wire'', 3 May 2013. Accessed 12 May 2013.</ref><ref>Luke Villapaz. "[http://www.ibtimes.com/peoples-daily-tower-chinese-newspaper-receives-widespread-criticism-its-phallic-shaped-building People's Daily Tower: Chinese Newspaper Receives Widespread Criticism For Its Phallic-Shaped Building]". ''International Business Times'', 3 May 2013. Accessed 12 May 2013.</ref>
===Hyde Park Obelisk, Sydney=== The {{convert|22|m|adj=on}} high [[Hyde Park Obelisk]], located in [[Hyde Park, Sydney|Hyde Park]], [[Sydney]] [[Australia]] at the intersection of [[Elizabeth Street, Sydney|Elizabeth Street]] and [[Bathurst Street, Sydney|Bathurst Street]], is both a former sewer ventshaft and a notable landmark in the Sydney CBD.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sydneywater.com.au/SW/water-the-environment/what-we-re-doing/Heritage-search/heritage-detail/index.htm?heritageid=4571022|title=Heritage detail - Sewer Vent (The Obelisk)|publisher=Sydney Water|date=28 February 2014|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> Its phallic appearance was emphasised on 7 November 2014, when the AIDS Council of NSW (ACON) temporarily installed a giant condom over the Obelisk as part of a HIV awareness campaign. The installation generated a lot of media interest—including many phallic innuendos<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/nov/07/giant-pink-condom-hits-sydney-to-remind-gay-men-safety-comes-first|title=Giant pink condom hits Sydney to remind gay men safety comes first|publisher=''The Guardian''|date=7 November 2014|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thevine.com.au/life/news/a-giant-hot-pink-condom-is-currently-covering-hyde-parks-obelisk-20141107-289631/|title=A giant hot pink condom is currently covering Hyde Park's Obelisk|publisher=''The Vine''|date=7 November 2014|accessdate=8 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141107153454/http://www.thevine.com.au/life/news/a-giant-hot-pink-condom-is-currently-covering-hyde-parks-obelisk-20141107-289631/|archivedate=7 November 2014|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/nsw/giant-pink-condom-lowered-onto-sydneys-hyde-park-obelisk-to-fight-aids-in-nsw/story-fni0cx12-1227115351946?nk=d41d5c369adac541ab96fbe07d9e7357|title=Giant pink condom lowered onto Sydney’s Hyde Park Obelisk to fight AIDS in NSW|publisher=''The Daily Telegraph''|date=7 November 2014|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref>—and drew the ire of the Australian Christian Lobby.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/finance/business/wendy-francis-on-the-giant-pink-condom-on-hyde-park-obelisk/story-fnki1jcy-1227115540255|title=Wendy Francis on the giant pink condom on Hyde Park Obelisk|publisher=''news.com.au''|date=7 November 2014|accessdate=8 November 2014}}</ref>
